segments.text: The 6th, and we're at 713 East 30th Street in the beautiful home.
Paul Van Ryper and Paul, say a sentence and let's check.
This is the old Cabot House, which is on the National Register of Historic Places.
It's the oldest house of any size in the county.
Okay, now...

Paul, to introduce yourself to someone who may hear this tape or read the transcript many years from now, describe your background, where you grew up, where you went to college, and experience before you came to A&M.
Okay, I was born in Indiana in La Porte.
My father was school superintendent, which is a background I don't wish on people often.
He was school superintendent my entire high school period.
He was commissioned in World War I, and I never lived in the ports but a few months.
He was commissioned to give, as a captain in what's called the sanitary corps, to give training to shell-shocked and insane soldiers, rehabilitation work in

veteran's hospitals in New Jersey and Virginia then he came back to Indiana and became superintendent at Franklin Indiana and then Lebanon Indiana where I grew up he was superintendent there from 1922 to 1942 and I view Lebanon Indiana as my hometown and as a native Hoosier
I went to high school in Lebanon, was lucky enough to be valedictorian, and got a full scholarship ride to DePaul.
My father and uncle, who had gone to Franklin College, Indiana, did not like DePaul because of some football experiences.
And my uncle, who was a corporation lawyer in Chicago, offered to pay the difference between what it
would cost me to go to DePaul and anywhere else.
He was definitely favoring Harley, which at that time I could have got in.
Everybody was looking for students.
This is 1934, the middle of the Depression.
Well, that, of course, committed me to DePaul.
So, I went to DePauw.
I thought it was just about the right size.
I had come from a high school which had a graduating class of 79, and I wasn't prepared for a big institution.
I thoroughly enjoyed DePauw.
I graduated as Phi Beta Kappa, major in history.
I would have majored in political science, but didn't much care for the political science professors, so I had a minor in
social studies.
I applied then.
I got interested in the University of Chicago.
This is the heyday of Hutchins.
The second.
How big was DePaul?
DePaul was about 1,200 then.
It's now something like 2,200 there about.
It had been in the 20s up to about 1,500.
So I got a half scholarship to Chicago and decided I was going to proceed and major in political science, which interested me.
I might just as well have gone to graduate work.
There was 20% unemployment at that time.
In addition, the major source of employment was the public service, which was expanding rapidly, as you know.
What year was that?
I enter DePauw in 34, graduate 38.
I enter Chicago the fall of 38.
And I finish my doctor prelims.
the summer of 41.
I'm working on my doctoral dissertation, and December 7 occurs.
I have a very high draft number, 8,500 or something like that, so I'm in no danger of being drafted immediately.
But I, in 1939, applied for a reserve commission in the Army.
It looked like things were coming to a head, so it didn't take great brains to figure that out.
Well, the Quartermaster Corps was the only part of the Army I could get a commission in without having prior military service.
So I often laughed at my background.
My background for commission was the 10 series of correspondence courses.
including truck driving by correspondence, if you can imagine.
At the University of Chicago, they did weekend military training for civilians.
And they did a series of six weekends.
I took that.
Chicago also had a rifle range.
And I qualified for an expert bad small bore.
They didn't have caliber 30.
And on July 2, 1942, I was called up as a second lieutenant and sent to Fort Lee, Virginia.
Let's back up just a second.
How, where, under what circumstances did you hear about the happenings on December 7 in Pearl Harbor?
Oh, I was living in a dormitory room on the campus.
right across from the place where the atom bomb was begun.
And at that time we were mad as hell because our squash courts had gone for reasons unknown.
Did anybody, did you students know what was going on underneath the stadium?
No, except classified.

uh information and nobody was talking were there any graduate students that you all knew that were working on that project not that we were aware of so uh excuse me go ahead quite secretively uh as i say we were all furious because our best squash courts went and i played squash a great deal then
My major professor at Chicago was Leonard White, who's considered the kind of founder of modern public administration.
He did the first textbook in 1926.
He had just come back from three years as U.S. civil service commissioner.
Probably
I pointed to that at the suggestion of Charles Merriam, who was head of political science at Chicago for years and who was a personal friend of FDR's.
Interesting backgrounds there.
White encouraged me to get a commission.
So I was called up before my doctoral dissertation was done.
It was just as well I wasn't getting anywhere with it at that time and my mind was not.
Now you had changed to political science.
Yeah.
How did that change come about?
Well I had started in to be political science at DePaul but I didn't care for the faculty and I liked history anyways so I combined the two and my dissertation was the
History of the United States Civil Service, which later I parlayed into a book, which was published finally in 1958.
My dissertation, 1900 to 1940, I parlayed it back to 1789 and forward to the date of publication, 1958.
I went in the military.
I don't know how much you want a little bit, because it is relevant.
I was sent to Fort Lee, Virginia, reported in, and I was assigned within a week to the 9th Quartermaster Training Regiment, which was black troops.
Fort Lee had two black regiments and five white, plus the Quartermaster School.
And I served for
let's see, about 18 months as an officer in an all-black outfit except white officers, black negro that is, non-coms and enlisted men.
Let's venture on that just a second.
What kind of nomenclature, what
What identifying words were used then by serious professionals like you to identify those men?
At that time, we spoke about colored troops.
And they accepted that?
Yes, there was no... And basically, where were they from geographically?
Primarily from the South.
We had some from New York.
who were not accustomed to going to the back of the bus.
And there would be, periodically.
This is Virginia.
Virginia.
Near Petersburg, Virginia, just outside.
And you were a newcomer to the South.
To the South.
But I seemed to get on.
So there was a tendency, if you got on with black troops, to keep you there.
Well, I'd been there about 18 months, and I knew I was going to be, the officers were turning over and being sent to Europe.
I had an interesting situation, very briefly.
When I tell the Corps of Cadet students the promotion possibilities in wartime, I was a second lieutenant three months,
a first lieutenant nine months and when I had to be a captain for over two years before major I thought that was a long time.
And so I was a captain by the time the end of the 18 months and our colonel had been the personnel director of
I think one of the large meatpacking firms, anyway.
He was W.W. Watson.
And I went to him and said, if I go overseas, could you put me with a white unit for a change?
He said, I'll try.
Said, you've done very well for me.
And so I went in April 44 with the 63rd Quartermaster Base Depot headquarters and headquarters company.

it was 36 officers and 118 enlisted men the top cadre for a quartermaster based depot when you had enough land to put one on and I was designated the purchasing and contracting officer and when the colonel said why that he said well I've

I don't have any person in contracting officer you've had some enough education you ought to be able to learn it so I said all right this suits me and we were formed from people who already had their background for example we had the captain who was in charge of
Cole had been the owner of a coal yard, this kind of background.
It wasn't a military outfit, except our commanding officer was West Point, Colonel Harding.
serial number 4204, which indicates his.
So, yeah, we had four full colonels in the outfit.
It was an outfit to run a large operation.
Well, we set sail for England on June 19th on a French luxury liner that had been pulled out of Brest Harbor.

to keep the Germans from getting it and then refitted for a troop ship and we sailed alone because we were faster than viewed as faster than the submarine so we got across to Liverpool without incident and spent a couple of weeks at the Seaforth barracks in Liverpool and then went for some depot
training experience, sort of, to a general depot, the quartermaster part of it, in Burton-on-Trent.
And they were losing their officers, so I became the S-3, the mansion training officer, for that for a couple of weeks, or three weeks.
And then
Prings were moving fast on the continent and on early, let's see, about August 9 or 10, we got on a train for Southampton.
A day later, we went across to land on Normandy.
Thank God it was in August, not in June.
And we landed at, I never can remember whether Utah or Omaha, landed on Utah Beach, I think.
One or the other, I'll have to look it up.
Without any problem.
We went over on a Belgian freighter, Leopoldville, which a month later was sunk in the channel.
But there were, we went across and we all wore gas masks.

the Germans have not broken through at St. Louis yet so we can hear the guns and so on although the US has air superiority there are no danger there's a flyover plane occasionally Midnight Charlie we called him who was obviously just kind of nobody fired at him let him look figured this would be discouraging enough to see how strength there was
Well, we'd been there a few days when Patton broke through.
And an interesting experience, which is, as far as I know, has not been written up.
I thought I would do it sometime, and time's getting short, so I'll either do it for three days.

we realized finally the beach command and we were as quartermaster we were helping assisting the beach command half at Utah and half at Omaha and I'm sorry and a few more back in Cherbourg the only full depot was at Cherbourg at that point it's the only place we had enough land to award quartermaster depot so

for three days Patton commandeered all the trucks from the beach that had been bringing supplies and loaded them with gasoline and supplies and he took off with all the beach trucks or nearly all of them and the way things were logistically on the beach is at any one time there are anywhere from 200 to 400 ships out there

in the English Channel and the what we called ducts ductworks holding a ton and a half I guess about that I'd have to check that come up and the nets would put two net loads in a duct and it would come back on land the nets would be unloaded in piles
they would be put on trucks and the trucks went to the interior depot.
No trucks.
The piles on the beach are getting to astronomical pyramidal proportions and the beach command doesn't know what to do and the problem is solved by one of our officers, Major Schaffner, who in
Private Life was a photographer in Indianapolis, Dale Shockner.
He said, look, can these ducks make it up the beach road?
If they can, we lay out a depot right above and unload and sort there.
And we don't have to use trucks to get the stuff off the beach.
and whatever trucks can then come in to the upper part and be loaded.
And sure enough, it worked.
I was assigned with a sergeant to go up and lay out the stakes for the long

runways that you send stuff down a roller conveyor and it's sorted out and all the beans here and all the potatoes there and all something else there and it had been mine presumably all the mines had been I discovered later that not all of them had done we I saw down at one field a mine exploded and knocked the track off a
Caterpillar.
But nevertheless, we went out and laid out and staked the thing, and this worked and worked fine.
So I give Schaffner credit for that problem.
I'll back up once further, because this hit us in Paris.
Then we were wondering,
where we were going to be sent.
They're now land for more.
And we were supposed to be sent to Metz.

Well, it turns out that the group who were to go to Paris, who were much senior to us, General Rogers could not stand the colonel commanding the unit that was scheduled for Paris, and he sent them to Metz.
and we got the Paris assignment.
We were the youngest depot unit in the UK and we got the choice assignment by that accident.
So we head for Paris on September 10th and set up the Quartermaster Depot in a French warehousing concern, 105 Rue d'Aubervilliers in
Oh, the working class suburb just north of Paris.
Well, be that as it may.
And in three weeks' time, we are supplying food, clothing, and gasoline to four field armies.
This is where the Army military preplanned organizational system does things that private enterprise couldn't have done from scratch in six months.
Within six weeks, we were from our little headquarters unit, we had
1,500 US military, about 2,000 French civilians and a battery of German PWs operating as an entity.
We had one problem.
We'd been there about three weeks when
suddenly in the Paris rail cars, rail yards, there's no railroad around the coast.
Everything comes into Paris and then has to go out from there.
That's why we were so central to four field armies for about three months.
Somebody sent 700 rail cars to us and 250 trucks all at once.
We have 26 warehouses that can unload at any one time two cars or three trucks.
Well, Quartermaster General sent down inspectors to find out what was going on and we were exonerated as all we did was to begin to unload things in between the tracks.
and unloaded them in the streets and it was the suburbs of Reveille.
Things in the streets.
And as our colonel told the inspecting officer, do you want trucks unloaded or pretty warehousing?
You can't have both right now.
So the person who had done this was nothing less than Colonel Florsheim.
What's his name?
Florsheim.
Florsheim Shoes.
As in, oh, OK.
The boss man of Florsheim Shoes who had done this to us.
And he got reamed, I'm sure.
Well.
Here's what happened to the best laid supply plans.
The ships that left New York were loaded carefully.
What would have been easiest was to put all the beans in one ship and all the
peas in another ship, but if you lost a ship, you lost the beans for the entire continent.
So every ship had six or eight items.
Now, here's what happened, you see.
They're in a hurry on the beach.
They put the nets into the hull.
Here are the six and eight items around the nets.
They're tossed in, and the nets are mixed.
They are dumped on the beach.
They are then sorted up on the beach.
They're re-sorted.
OK.
So the trucks bring them in to the depot.
And the 700 trucks have to be, and the rail cars, all have to be dumped.
and all resorted again.
So there's no simple way to solve this, and our records were an absolute mess because we started the death pool without a full set of documentation files.
We have things being tallied in by American soldiers, German PWs, French civilians, and what the hell they're tallying them in for, God only knows what the records show.
I later became director of the supply division.
First, I was moved from person and contracting officer to commanding officer of the depot supply company, which provided most of the warehousing.
And I became major and director of the supply division, which was the things that are like civilian stuff, office supplies, paint, et cetera, and so on, plus food.
I figured I had my records were good plus or minus fifty percent on any given item.
It took me about a year to re-warehouse the whole place.
Okay, as purchasing and contracting officer I wound up in charge of the produce for the American troops in the Paris area and for about a year I was buying
price produce for approximately a quarter of a million men.
It's an occupation I want nothing more to do with.
You can lose your shirt.
And I'm chuckling to myself.
I can't imagine anything in your background prepared you for this.
Nothing whatever, except a certain amount of flexibility.
I hired three Frenchmen.
We dealt with the Paris market through the French Ministry of Foods.
The arrangements were interesting because we bought things on reverse land lease.
The French government paid for whatever we bought.
And we had a consignment in the Paris market of produce.
France was quite self-sufficient in produce, in food of all kinds.
The only things in short supply then were meat, butter, and eggs because Normandy was shot up.
That was the meat, butter, and egg country.
So I dealt with the Paris market and made friends.
I had three assistants whom I kept in touch with for many years.
One is still living.
I just got a letter from him.
I wanted Frenchmen who were
without any possible taint of collaboration.
So I hired William Duncan, who was the son of a Canadian soldier and a Frenchwoman in World War I.
He'd lived in Canada for part of his life and had been in the resistance and he was totally bilingual, which was very helpful.
And I hired
Norman Pullen, who was the son of the British headmaster of the British school in Paris who'd been interned the entire war in Paris.
And the third was Joseph Kertetz, a Hungarian Jew, whom I'm still friends with, who had managed to save both himself and his parents in Vichy, France.
We gradually closed out the depot and I left in April 1946, came back and was discharged, remained in the reserve, and became a lieutenant colonel after a while.
In Ithaca I was asked if I wanted to be executive officer of an infantry regiment and I thought
Why the hell are you asking a quartermaster to be in charge of infantry?
Well, I had in between 55 and 60 gone and done the command general staff course in Leavenworth and the reserve version.
He said, you're the only one around who's done that.
I said, give me a day or two to think about it, but I declined it.
It was too much time.
So my military career was in effect.
I was in a reserve unit, a logistical unit, and enough to end up with a 15% military pension, which is useful.
But the experience was...
important I think in terms of my main field.
